posts.name: Shlomit
posts.cooked:
Our team has been focusing on enhancing our electronics layout and cable management during the off-season. We've noticed how poor cable routing can lead to several issues, such as loose connections, damaged wires, and unexpected robot behavior during matches. As a result, we're being more deliberate in our approach to these tasks.

I wanted to start a conversation and gather insights from other teams:

- What tools or materials do you use for reliable cable management?
- Do you have any go-to techniques or guidelines, like labeling wires, using CAD before soldering, or specific debugging tips for mid-match situations?

We currently utilize some tools, including zip ties, heat shrink for protection, Wagos, cable bundlers, and an energy belt. I'd love to hear how other teams handle their electronics!

I personally am not a big fan of WAGOs. I prefer Anderson Power Poles because  
a) they are a one-and-done solution—you crimp them once, and you can use them repeatedly without dealing with tangled wires from frequently disconnecting them, unlike Spark MAX wires.  
b) you can zip WAGO powerpoles together to prevent them from sliding apart.  
c) they can be connected to form a large block of powerpoles that can be easily unplugged or plugged together.  

If you decide to use WAGOs, I highly recommend this video from Team 11.  
Additionally, having flexible wire makes a big difference. We had some old, stiff wire that made bending and maneuvering challenging until we switched to PowerWerx wire, which has been much easier to handle.  
This thread has a lot of useful information as well.

posts.name: Shlomit
posts.cooked: We used Andersons this year as well. However, we found it challenging to crimp each one, so for most applications, we relied on WAGOs instead. Despite this, we did use Andersons for the NEO 550. We wondered if our technique was incorrect, but we consistently encountered difficulties with them, particularly when dealing with bendy wires, making them less reliable for our needs.

posts.name: Tristan Lall
posts.cooked:
A couple of suggestions for improving the PowerPole setup:

One option is to use the "SF" ("Super Flex") versions of the PowerPole crimp contacts. These are designed specifically for 10 AWG fine-stranded wire and can be crimped using regular tools like TriCrimp or the Anderson Power Products factory tooling. Notably, these contacts support a larger wire cross-sectional area of 6.0 mm² compared to the regular ones at 5.3 mm².

Another helpful technique is to use tiny needle-nosed pliers. Grip the back of the contact by inserting the tips of the pliers into the housing near the rear and along the diagonal edges. This method ensures the contact sits securely past the housing spring, especially useful when dealing with flexible, large-stranded wire.

Additionally, consider using either tiny zip ties placed within the housing or strong adhesive tape with a sticky, residue-free adhesive. These options can help secure the components effectively, complementing or serving as an alternative to the high detent force contacts, which may be less universally compatible and harder to install correctly.

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked: There’s actually a tool for inserting contacts into housings, although I’ve never seen a team use it. It’s a plastic cone that goes on the outside of the wire and pushes on the metal contact. We use these regularly at work for inserting pins into connectors. For 12 gauge wires, use M81969-14-04, which are affordable and might save you some hassle. (Image of the tool is attached below.)

Andersons for power, solder everything else. For quick tests, DuPonts and Wagos work well, alongside Weidmullers for ferrules. Use loom or cable track for long strips of wire in exposed areas. Other than that, your list looks good. Outside of the equipment perspective, the paradigm I've always followed is to create cable pathways all around the robot; every single cable must go through one of these paths. Usually, your paths will be decided by the rest of your robot; for example, our robot this year was very simple, and the final pathway was basically just a square. Some more small tips (no particular order or category): Utilize open spaces in tubes to protect and guide wires. Expose entire mechanisms to the robot by as few points as possible. One power pair for each motor controller (MC) and two CAN connectors. Solder all the CAN connectors together to make them into coherent units. This makes swapping in backups easier. Use hot glue for sketchy or important connections: RSL, RIO/PDH, CAN, any DIO/PWM ports. Avoid bending crimps too sharply. When soldering, twist the wires together to maximize cohesion before soldering. AND PLEASE USE FLUX! CAD your electronics, both for cable management and MC placement, and for knowing the true weight of the robot. You will not regret this. Recruit musicians and/or artists to your electrical subteam. Seriously, this actually works really well. Add a small amount of slack when cutting wires, both to reduce stress and to give a bit of extra leeway.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: We mainly used energy chain and zipties this year, and they worked really well.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked: Maybe tiny zip ties within the holes between the two housings could work. Powerwerx makes inserts specifically designed for that purpose. For example, 1732 uses 3D printed clips that look similar. We don't use WAGOs for high-current applications, except those integrated into the PDH (Power Distribution Hub). After another year, we might stop using WAGOs altogether. Andersons for power connections, JST-XH for sensors, and heat-shrink butt splices for CAN (Controller Area Network) are preferred alternatives.

Maybe tiny zip ties within the holes between the two housings could work for retention. You can also zip tie around the entire connector and between the wires instead of threading the tiny holes. Going around the outside allows for larger zip ties too; I’ve found that the super-tiny ones are a bit more fiddly to source and install than standard ones.

To OP, using 2102 sleeves for everything, especially wires we don’t expect to handle often like bellypan wiring, provides added protection for external runs or can act as an outer sheath for moving cables. Being able to see major pathways to individual modules/mechanisms also aids a lot when troubleshooting.

The weight penalty is minimal when using thin materials like split-loom sleeving. If you choose to sleeve wiring, make sure to avoid hiding connectors inside sleeves—they’re surprisingly easy to overlook when tracing wires.

Others have echoed this advice; steer clear of wago clamps, use hot glue for small connectors that aren’t easily zip tied, and plan out wiring during the design phase.

posts.name: Vaani Mathur
posts.cooked: Recruit musicians and/or artists to your electrical subteam. Elaborate :0? Edit: Just realized why: nimble fingers :).
Nimble fingers indeed enhance one's ability to manage complex wiring due to an improved sense of direction. Some might even argue that cable management itself is a form of art.

posts.name: Miles.D
posts.cooked: This year, we wired everything under our belly pan and ended up with a messy pile of wires and loose connections.

posts.name: James O’Leary
posts.cooked: This year, a helpful approach for managing wires involved creating a hole pattern on the bellypan, allowing easy placement of 3D printed components and the routing of zip ties without concerns about sticking to surfaces. This method simplifies wiring and facilitates the repositioning of subsystems more efficiently.

What specifically did you struggle with? Struggling with crimping the contact onto the wire? Inserting the contacts into the housing or having the housings slip apart? Also, what size contacts do you use (we use PP45)? I also recommend the PowerWerx TriCrimp tool—it's what we use, and it’s great.
